Onthe 9th November, Delegates from the several
Counties and Parishes Of the State of Louisiana,
friendly to the reelection Of ]. G. Adams, met at
Baton Rouge, in that State, to form an electoral
Ticket, &c. &c Judge Tessier in the chair, and J.
!, Canonge, Secretary.


The following Address and Resolutions were un-
anlmous!y adopted.


ADDRESS.


The present crisis of the great American family
iswlthout precedent since the moment that 1t placed
itself under that glorious constitution which has ell
eyated it 10 the distinguished rank IT now enjoys
among the most civilized nations OF the earth Tins
CRISIS, gradually approaching tor these three years
past, menaces our dearest interests those sacred
principles which animated the immortal authors OF
our independence seem already to be forgotten The
impartial observer, who traces the movements OF
our parties is induced to believe that tatgued with
an ever increasing prosperity, with freedom each
nay better appreciated, the source OF our lncom-
parable felicity, we are already so desenerated, ms
oloo, without horror, upon the possibility OF CIV
ls ourselves master, and submitting our necks to
The yoke. Until nov, the opinion universally re-
ceyed, in this our most favored country, was that,
oaspire to govern the Republic. an intimate know
ledge of the law OF nations and Of the political and
commercial relations of all civilized nations among
themselves and with US, was indspensably neces-
sary. That, further, such candidate should be an
,rfeproachable patriot and sincere lover of the
'u.,hion and of the protecting principles of civil
i'oerty. But new change seems to be operating
and endeayouring to overthrow the most manifest
ana salutary doctrines. Instead of the learning I'M
now required the eclat of glory is to be the title
~ all Offices. The experience and the intorma-

to allow to the English the free navigation OF the
Mississippi, from its mouth to its source.


There is not one of those eight accusations which
can be sustained by proof or plausible argument.
The least reflection will suffice, to the unprejudced
man, who has some knowledge OF facts and OF the
most respectable precedents, to discover and esti-
mate the injustice of each. Let US examine them
severally.


lst accusation: ssAdams, it is said, has been
made president against the will OF the people Jack
son the choice of the people"


In state where the people had no part in the
formation of the constitution, it might be possible
that election made similar to the election OF John
Quincy Adams, would be considered as made against
the will of the people. Yet, even, then, we should
think that it was necessary that majority OF the
people should declare, not only against him, but IN
favor of one of his competitors. But IN repub-
lie, such as ours where all powers derived from
the people, where the constitution is the work OF
their special manufactures, instructed to form 1t for


them it is neither Just nor reasonable to assert, that
such AN election as that of John Quincy Adams has


been made against their will. Was it not the Peo-
Pile themselves who required, that when no candl-
date had the absolute orty OF votes IN the elec-


toral college, the house of representatives should
choose, from the three who had obtained the great.


est number. TO say, that in each case, the person


chosen is chosen against the will of the people, be-





does it not render nugatory the provision OF the


constitution, which delegates to the house OF repre-


sentatyes the choice, when no candidate has an abb


solute majority ?lf the people had wished that the


candidate who should have the relative majority
: should be elected, would they in such case have


transferred the right of choice to their representa-


tiyes? And the right to make choice would 1t not


be mockery, if the candidate who had the most


sufrages must necessarily be elected, to comply


H. en- How bp In


has only the relative majority Of electoral votes, be


more considered as the choice Of the people, than
he who having fewer of these sudrages, has IN his


favor the majority of the house OF representatives
/ What are those electors? Are they other than the


simple organs of the will of the people And the


representatives are they not also the organs and


Interpreters Of the will of the people?


But further, in establishing the real proportion,
between the electoral votes which ea-h candidate
has received, and the votes which have been given


in each State it is proved, that Adams had SO l-69
votes Jackson had but sc 1-83; Crawford AZ l-23;
and Clay 27 l-7O. This calculation, made and


published since the 29th January, 1928. IN the Ma


tonal Journal and the correctness and exactitude oil
which has neverb been contested ndisputaby proves,


that it is Adams, and not Jackson, who is what the
opposition is pleased to call the real candidate oihe
; people,
: cd accusation :--"Adams has been raised to the
: presidency by bribery and corruption"
. This caunnious proposition, advanced and re-
peated by 80 many Interested echos, IN all parts o
the United States, for more than two years and 9
i half had been Justly appreciated since the moment
t it was denied by the Secretary Of stae upon whom
J. was evident they endeavored more particularly t
rest the odi0us weight. But il, after the inextrica
9 BILE dilemma in which this able orator had put the
man from whom the calumny proceeded there re
i NAMED any doubts in the mind of any honest citizen
fho nf Mr. ISuc tied
s. ing witness by these hardy accusers, has forever
/ disspated them and since then, no man who re
CARDS his reputation, or the justice OF the peo
pie, as much he ought to deest all odlous perse
!. cution will allow himself to repeat this accusation
J, TThe 3rd accusation relates to his recommenda
" ton of an Observatory the fourth to the establish
= nent OF an University in the District OF Columbia
y y the fifth to his being IN favor OF internal improve
" men the sixth to his opposition to the acquisition
Y of Louisiana the seventh-hs having voted for
q q or not opposing the passage of law which tool
= from them all their rights TO the vacant lands-Now
= the 3d. 4th and 5th of these accusations, the Con
~ =, vention commend--showng that these recommen
- dations ofhe President not only good in them
I; selves, but agreeably to the recommendations o
:, : his predecessors. The sixth is shown not TO b.
- true-by his actual vote for the purchase--and tn
70 seventh is fully met, by Mr.. Adams absence Oh
h. service in Europe.


: :" 9th accusation -" At Client he offered to sur
of render to the English the free navigation OF tn
e Mississippi, from its mouth to its source.
~ BY the treaty Of 1888, between Great Britain
"a, and the United States, the free navigation OF th'
r. Mississippi guaranteed to England, who on he'
IN part accorded to then young republic, the righ
o of fishing in all the and coasts OF her domains
Al in America.


fl At the negotiations at Ghent, three of the com
in mssioners, Messrs. Gallatin, Adams and Bayard
p sensible of the importance of preserving the righ
~ of fishing and of especially of drying the fish upoI
he the coasts of the English possessions, desired it

military services. Such are the doctrines which a
party, as indefatgable in its efforts as unscrupulous
IN its means, attempts to propagate Where s the
sincere friend to the Union, who does not ardenty
desire to see crushed the projects, and destroyed
the hopes of such party Who is he who does
not feel himself disposed to exert his individual ef
forts, to remove far from us the caamities which
will inevitably overwhem us, the attempts OF some
members OF this party we're crowned with all the
success which they dare hope to obtain! These
reflections have determined the delegates of the !
friends of the present Administration of the United
States assembled in convention, to expose to the
people of whom they have the honour to form
part faithful narrative OF the circumstances
which have given birth to this convention, and ofI
the motives which have guided the numerous friends
of the present administration, in the part which they
have taken to pronounce in its favour, and to oppose
themselves to the election of General Jackson to
the presidency.


John Quincy Adams had served his country for
more than thiry-ve years, in various civil employ
ments, all of the most delicate nature, and difficult
| to execute, when, in 1926, he elected Presl-
dent of the United States Among other celebrat-
cd persons, he had for competitor the hero of the


9th Of January. Iie affecting generosity really
chlvalrous, hastened on the day of installation, to
cordially congratulate his successful rival But this
so interesting manifestation Of such noble senti-


mens, was, alas never to be repeated In fine,


the most jealous partzans of the unsuccessful


didae dissatisfied with their failure, did not hesi-


tate 10 contradict by their conduct, the sincerity of
the General in his laudable act ON this solemn
| caslon.


From the moment when the new president COM


rnenced the formation Of his cabinet. strong oppo


sition on their part manifested itself The norn-


nation of secretary Of state, confirmed by twenty


seven senator's, opposed by fourteen votes; and


Immediately succeeded the most harsh reflections,


and the most degrading insinuaons to the former


expressions ofmagnanmity and courtesy In word.
a violent opposition was organized and yet, upon
what was it foundedP Was it upon the supreme
law of the general gnod? No: this opposition did


not blush to assert. that they wished to put out all


the members of the new administration, right or


wrong. and were they 'as pure as the angels OF hea


ven " aud in the delirum Of their raging fever, what
did they not atempta Every one knows that. at


the last presidential election of all the candidates
for the presidency, one had obtained Of the peo-


pie. or Of the electoral college, the majority regur-


ed by the constitution: Jackson had in his favour the
/, votes 90 eectors Adams 81; Crawford Al; Clay 81
3 In this state of things, it became the duty of the
;, house of representatives, to make choce among


the three highest candidates, as required by the con


stitution; and in the performance Of this consttu
h tona duty, the house determined in favor of Johr
Is Quincy Adams. The opposition, composed OF dit
a erent materials who found themselves obliged IL
h renounce the brilliant hopes they had severally in
70 dulged in, and rritated with result SO dheren
~ from what each had promised hlmsef; this opposi


ton pretended to find in the constitution, until nov
= considered perfect, radical defect, to which alon


they attributed the i'll success of the disappointed


candidate. From that time they dreamed OF moth
= ing but an amendment to the constitutions and du
al ring thirds of the ensuing session OF congress
a unhappily celebrated, thev made the most astonsh
Mt ing efforts to amend it, They endeavoured to abrc


,l tho hong nf
" representatives. the right, in the exercise ot which
had declared, of three candidates balotted tor tina


Adams was the most worthy. They endeavoure
In to give to the people the immediate election OF tn


president; to enact that he should not be re-esbl


after the expiration Of his four years; finally, I


take from the president, and give to congress, po"
ny ers which by their nature alone belong to the e!
ea ecutive, and which. If usurped, would make eac
ell legislature, in his state or his district petty d
ys penser of employments and honors. For what en-
ms were all their vain Efforts made? Against whol
ITS were they directed! They made with the OF
ed ly view of degrading the president they were d
OF rected against him personally. And why Jol'
he Quincy Adams? Had he not the talents the earf
OF ing the merit, or the required virtues to hold tn
lh reins of government of the republic? distinguish
ch ed writer. profound politician, consummate states
M man, an enlightened philosopher, by forty years
as experience in the thorny career of public affair
iv- America would in vain seek another citizen to b
to compared to him ]; Europe would not find, anon
re- her immense population. single man his superior
at, Yet this opposition dares to reproach him wit
having been president against the wish OF the people
md Andrew Jackson, according to them, was the rel
ing chuice of the people. they reproach Adams WI!
es- having been elevated to the presidency by bargai
an and corruption; they make It crime, that he r.
the commended the construction oan observatory; the
vl charge him with another, for having proposed I'll
ng, establishment of a university in the District
est Columbia they reproach him with being in favor
I'M internal improvements they accuse him with ha
nirchase 0f InuSiana: OF haYlnr Y

because at London they well knew, that the navi-
CATION of the Mississippi, subject to the regulations
of our customs, not an equivalent Tor the right
of fishing and curing the fish, claimed IN ITS stead
Thay remembered that they had the freedom OF
this navigation since 1908, to the declaration ofwar
between the two countries, and that it was never
used except to New-Orleans. In fine, they knew
Iby experience, that such clause in the treaty
would be of no service to the English commerce.


These facts are incontrovertible they have been


known generally, since the treaty which, IN giving
us peace without restored to to the enjoyment Of
all rights, of which military despotism has de-
prved us. And if proofs necessary of these
facts, Louisiana counts among her citizens, man
who has personal knowledge of them, and would at
any moment render just homage TO the truth.


So that whatever be the efforts Of a vrulent OPP


position, hs last accusation is destitutute OF foun-
dation as all the preceding ones.


After having sufficiently examined this long list


of imaginary complaints, urged with such assurance


and violence, and zealousy repeated every


where, let turn attention to the candidate IN


whose favor it is desired that John Quincy Adams


should descend from the eminent post which he fills


in manner so honorable for himself and useful to
! his fellow-citizens.


Let US first inquire, by what claims this cand-


date recommends himself to the people ; and then.


if there do not exist against his election most weigh


ty and well founded objections.


! Andrew Jackson, though young during our revo-
luton, and incapable of rendering any remarkable


service, has been represented as one ofits heroes


but by what trait OF herosm has he been distinguish
ed by what brilliant action has he signallzed his
talents and his patriotism In vain do we consult
history; she is silent as to his deeds
t AS LAWYER as Judge, as member OF the convention


of his state as member of Congress. we know not OF


any discourse, Of any opinion, of any written re-
port, which could do honor to an ordinary man.


But say his friends he is Just. he is liberal if he
lis and bo rkablp {urh
his prompt and decided character, and the correct
! ness Of his Judgment.


He is lust and liberal !! Judge by his conduct to-
wards the honorable Henry Clay. On what was
4 founded the accusation made by him against this


distinguished citizen? Had he any proof? lle has
presumed to call to his aid the tes,imon9 of Mr..
Buchanan, his friend Buchanan has denied all his
n assertions.


. He is Just and liberal 4! Judge by his conduct
i: towards mr.. FuIwar skipwh. When the latter So
i cits appointment the General hastens TO defeat his


application sand the better to attain his end. he rep
ri resented him traitor tohis country. in letter that


he supposed no other than the person to whom it
q was addressed would read and upon whom depend
ed the employment that Mr.. Skipwlth desired to "b-


tain


o He is remarkable for his energy, his prompt and


decided character. and the correctness Of his udg-
). ment =! Are these the qualities that qualify man
= for the performance of the delicate. diff cult and


complicated duties he is called upon to fulfil. as pres
= iden of the United States They suffice for SOL
der; but for the first magistrate ofthe Union No.
- Nature may make general shut education alone,
Z statesman. He who wishes to become one must
Y devote himself to the study OF the laws and instu
tons of his country to history, to the internal and


external relations Of all countries, to the character
Of the inhabitants. the laws Of nations to the SCI
.. .. ence of government.


y But say his friends, fhe be elected, he will COM
: pensate for his own want Of talents and acquire
: ments. by the prudence and judgement with which
e he will compose his cabinet.


H. Thus the subordinate members Of the administra-
a ton must and will have all the required qualities.
v while the chief magistrate shall be incapable OF di-


recting them, or of judging Of their acts. Like cer
= tain monarchs, who reign BY divine right, he is to
~ receive, without being of any use to his country,
r. all the honors and emoumens intended to be the fit
* reward of civil labors and Of real services
v Where, then, is the redectng man, who in admit
n ting to the fullest extent the high praises avshed
NJ upon Gen. jackson by his most devoted partzans,
can believe that he is fit for the place to which they
OF would elevate him, only inasmuch as that place is
he other claims than those already mentioned, is this
IN candidate offered to the people for their sufrages


Ia it for the victory he in this state. obtained
T. the British God forbid that we should wish to
he detact from the glory which may have clothed the


general. in the memorable though short campaign of
in the winter of 1914 and 1875 But since when, has
military prowess become the certain passport to the
,r presdencye Have we sunk to that depth Of moral
ut and political depravation that can consider the
ls highest civil employment, created for the good Of


the public, of right the recompence of brilliant
L military actions2


1, Rome had her Caesar England her Cromwell.
1t France her Napoleon. Mexico her Iturbide Let
us be wiser than these nations at least profit by
their lessons, and suffer not ourselves to be dazzled
H. l...4. y.
